They were too hard and something was very off about the interior. Either there was too much flour, or the shrimp was too mushy. It just wasn't the typical juicy shrimp interior, and the mayo sauce should not have been wholly necessary to rescue the shrimp. Finally, I'd have to classify the taro dumplings as another letdown. They were smaller than expected, and not as flavorful. I appreciate that they weren't dripping with oil, but that's not why I eat dim sum.

Prices are were $2.28-$3.98 per dish, and $1.00 per person for hot jasmine tea. Service was surprisingly decent, with quick responses to such concerns as lack of soy and XO sauces on the table, requests for a to-go box, and closing the check. All of these were positives, but not enough to outweigh the boredom of the majority of the meal.

KJ Dim Sum just didn't live up to their reputation. This would be a 7/10 if I could rate it that way. I don't get decimals in this 5-star scale, and the disappointments today outweighed the few positives, so I'm saddened but content to round it down. I'd easily stop by again to ask for egg tarts and possibly cheong fun to-go, and that's about it.

This is a pretty good place to go if your  craving Chinese food. I have been here for dim sum and dinner.
Dimsum: selections are small compared to others dim sum places I have been too. The food was served from the carts, which is personally my favorite. The food was good and flavorful. 

Dinner. I ordered the fried rice with beef. Yummy! 
String beans:wowzers 
Fried tofu with shrimp: okay 
Chicken : can order whole or half. Pretty delicious. 
All the food came in a generous portion. The price for the food is expensive but it is the way it is bc its in a casino. Overall delicious

Authentic and nice for a city with no dim sum but the har gau is a bit small and had a taste like lotus leaf as though instead of being steamed on parchment paper they were steamed on cabbage or lotus leaf- these were disappointing but the shrimp dishes and tofu claypot were really good.
This would get 4 stars but the service was really slow and not that friendly. I had to ask three times for hoi sin and the tea came out warm instead of hot they need to tweet some dishes to get a 4 and I hope they do!!

There is something very comforting about dim sum... it's fast, it's cheap, it's warm and savory and it gives you the same freedom of variety as tapas does.  I love dim sum, and I have been used to the best in Manila because of our proximity with China.  But when we moved here to Vegas, it's been quite a challenge looking for good dim sum.  Thanks to the suggestion of a dear friend, we've decided to give it a go.  The first thing you immediately notice is the vibrancy of the place.  High ceilings, uncrowded tables, red walls, soft lighting and very clean/crisp table cloths.  So often you see dim sum places pay little attention to details. (The bathroom is just next door and very nice.)  

We came early thinking to avoid the crazy rush hour which we did, but unfortunately could not order anything off the dim sum menu since the chef arrives at 11:15am.  Make sure you go after that time of you want to enjoy their fried rice, noodles or other entrees.  But you will have plenty to choose from the dim sum carts whizzing by - from congee/rice porridge with century egg, silken tofu, fried shrimp wantons, egg custards, taro cakes, pork buns and dumplings.  Our favorites were the steamed pork buns, hargaw or shrimp dumplings and the sweet spare ribs.  They tasted like they were all freshly made and although they still do not quite compare to the stuff we grew up with, esp from Binondo (Chinatown)... they are the best dim sum I've had so far in Vegas.

If I had one small quibble, it's that the soy sauce in their Kikkoman jars did not taste like Kikkoman.  Heh.

My wife and I ate here twice. The first time, it wasn't that bad. The food was okay. Nothing spectacular and nothing special. The service was just okay. We ordered some fried rice that they never put in and we had to inquire repeatedly about it. It finally arrived after we were full. 

FLASH FORWARD to today. We dined there with some friends. It took FOUR servers to come to our table to get our drink orders and then another few for us to FINALLY get some water, soy sauce and some orders in. Was it because we weren't Chinese. Yes, I'm using the race card because all the other Patrons who were Chinese got waters without having to repeatedly be ignored and passed by. Lastly, although we were done, not a single person came to even ask if we're ready for our checks, refill waters, ask us if we're alive!! WORST SERVICE EVER! AND THE FOOD... well it's not worth the service. Not even a small bit!! Never coming back to this joint!

So, after my experience with Dim Sum at Cathay House, and so many of my friends swearing by this place, I had to try it.
Sadly, it was, IMO, not as good as CH. There wasn't one vegetable at all. Not one. I dont need a massive amount, but it's nice to get some greens when eating all that pork!
We tried quite a few of the same things that we had at CH, and I just liked the flavor better at CH.
The service is very good, and the price can't be beat. Our table was full with food, and it came to $14PP.
I left full and satisfied, but doubt I will return.

A very good dim sum. But a few items here and there were down right inedible, so you'll have to pick and choose with a discerning eye. 

My breakdown:
2 stars for food
1 star for dim sum service
1 star for chili sauce

Yes, 1 full star just for their own homemade condiment. That's how dang good that chili sauce was. Pretty much order anything that can be dipped into that sauce ... Your dim sum will magically taste better. 

Don't believe me?  I even took a picture. In fact, it was the only picture I took!  And it is also the only reason I am writing this review. 

KJ's chili sauce. Everything else is for dipping only.
Both the Shu Mai and Ha Gow had a very strange taste, not bad, just different from the norm. Nice place to eat, give it a shot.

Really good dim sum place located inside the Rio!   Minus one star because some of the items off the cart weren't that hot and I hate when they try to shove plates on you that you don't want to order, or perhaps you already have enough to eat.  

I noticed a lot of Chinese people in here, which is always a good sign!  Our bill for 2 people came to $26 and we took a bunch home.  We did order too much, so possibly next time it would be less.  If you like Dim Sum, definitely stop by this spot.  They serve from 11am-2pm.

P.S.  You really don't need to valet to eat here.  They have a big lot right outside the entrance where you can self park.  Save your tip money and park yourself.

I get to know about this restaurant from local Las Vegas Chinese restaurant waiter. She told me when I visited the restaurant that Rio dimsum is the best in Vegas. Ii have not gotten so much luck with dimsum in LV. We used to go to seafood harbour in Speing Mountain but after today visit, I'd start going to KJ dimsum because it is so much better (tastier, fresher and better service).

This restaurant used dimsum cart that made it more traditional feeling. I quickly grab the traditional dimsum like BBQ pork bun, siew may, ha kao, chicken feet and spare ribs. Cooking dimsum spare ribs and chicken feet are few of the more complex task and this restaurant did well. Overall it is delicious ... I added extra portion on chicken feet as a result.

The porridge is good and tasty as well.

Their chilli sauce is rather unique (unusual than the normal Chinese chilli oil), but it tastes good.

The service is VERY good, as our request is executed flawlessly and timely. 

The only opportunity of improvement is in the variety of the food, few we need to order separately.
Food is just ok nothing to write about and service is lacking. I can't recommend thus place to anyone.

Just had an excellent meal!  I was skeptical because the reviews weren't all good, but decided to ignore them and try it anyways. We were seated immediately, and as soon as we told them we were having dim sun, had two different trays at our side to select from.  We chose eight different selections and each one was perfect.  Our service couldn't have been better and we will definitely be back.

Good food, but the dinner prices are a bit over the top. I strongly recommend going during lunch, you can't really beat it, but the prices at dinner are hard to justify.

I'll be a lunch regular, but I'll never be back for a dinner

KJ Dim Sum & Seafood is my one and only choice in Vegas for dim sum...especially considering that some of my favorites have been closed down for some health concerns...while KJ on the other hand continues to pass inspections and stay open...which makes me feel well and think that something going on here is good for me and you.

I have only come here for lunch for Dim Sum cart services where they circle the restaurant with stacked carts of Dim Sum items for you to select from and satisfy your appetite.  I am fairly well educated on Chinese culture and food but not an expert who regularly enjoys lots of the selections they have to offer. Still what I can tell you is that the Dim Sum offered at KJ is fresh, warm, and simply showcases the ingredients. 

Almost all the time we wait for a while for the seating...even though they are fair, as I sit waiting, I sometimes feel inadequate for not speaking fluent Cantonese, but that all changes when we are seated and the Dim Sum carts start rolling our way. Don't be afraid of ordering...just point to the food that excites you and pair your food with some hot tea. They will even tell you what's inside each item if you ask. Do make a point to come here before noon on the weekends and you will have your table in no time.

Pricey, mediocre at best.
Homemade potstickers are OK, not amazing.
Clams with ginger-scallion sauce are good quality, but the sauce is a too oily and unappealingly thick and not usable as a sauce you would actually eat on your rice. If you must, get the black bean sauce and request 'low oil'. You'll probably get 'high saliva' ha ha ;)
House Lo Mein comes out kind of oily as well. Again, ask for 'low oil' if you gotta get it.

Management is a bit odd, a holdover trait from the original Spring Mountain Road location where you get a completely different menu w/no specials (and a fork) if you don't speak Chinese.

Dim Sum here is pretty average - it may even make you realize that you don't actually like Dim Sum. Kind of like jazz. We're told that it's good and that we should appreciate it, but the nuts of it are that it kind of sucks. Eating lukewarm food that was cooked 5 hours ago off of a rolling cart is just dumb.

If you're hankering for Chinese and are staying in the Rio, you're probably better off hitting the Rio Buffet and at least getting some crab legs out of the deal. 

Free tea is cool. Good on them. I was expecting to get snuck for at least $2 per tea drinker, but didn't.

This is the worst Chinese restaurant I've ever eaten at in Vegas.  The food was subpar, portions were small, ridiculous prices, no free refills on soft drinks, and the waiter was a little rude.  No wonder when we came for dinner, the place was empty.  We should have went down to Spring Mountain road, where the REAL Chinese restaurants were.  Three thumbs down (if I had a third thumb).  Beware of this place and avoid at all cost!!

This place is terrible. We went there for din sum, but it turned out ther was no more din sum then. We stayed anyway and ordered five dishes for 4 persons. One of the dish, steamed fish, was recommended by the waiter. We asked about the price and the waiter told us it would be $38, about 2 lbs. So, we said ok. The fish dish took a long time and we were joking that they must have gone fishing. When it finally came, we were mostly full. Then came the bill, and there was a $104 dish! We were really surprised and asked what it was. It was the fish! It was supposed to be $38/lb, and the fish weighed 2.7 lb! The fact was none of us heard that it was $38 per pound. The bill was presented to us by someone we had not seen, and the waiter was nowhere to be seen. When we questioned the bill, another person came up and said something like "of course it was $38 per pound..." No apology even for confusion or anything like that sort. We paid the bill, feeling cheated. Now coming to think of it, the fish could not have weighted 2.7 lbs. I often steam fish myself and a 2 lb fish is already pretty big, and our fish that day was at most 2lbs.
I would give it no star if possible.

Countless times I have waited in the Carnival buffet line wondering why I am waiting when I could walk in to that great smelling dim sum place across the way. First of all, just because you sell appetizer sized portions of certain foods does not make you a dim sum restaurant.  Having eaten in San Francisco at some of the best Dim Sum locations where the food arrives on carts and you choose what you want for small prices, I was a bit surprised to find that this is nothing more than a chinese restaurant with some unusual items on the menu like clay pots.  The prices, while good for chinese food are not great for dim sum and you won't be able to try 20 different selections unless you want to spend a ton.    The food we ordered was mixed.  The lobster spring rolls had decent chunks of what appeared to be lobster but had no lobster taste to it.  In fact, they were ultra bland.  The walnut shrimp was tasty as was the sizziling seafood which included scallops, calamari, an unidentifyable fish, shrimp and more.  The sweet and sour pork was also lacking in flavor but was not overly soggy.  They are less than generous on the rice portions.

I agree with other reviewers that services is lacking and there is absolutely no atmosphere in this place so don't expect a romantic meal.  I am sure there are better Dim Sum locations within 20 miles of this place.

Beside there is no difference in taste compare to any other regular Chinese restaurant you could find anywhere, I would like to talk about their service and ethic of the this restaurant.
I lost a wallet in this restaurant $600 cash drivers license, credicards within. there were about 4 cameras on the corners, Me and my girlfriend were the second guest. When I notice I left my wallet in the restaurant, I immediately went back to restaurant in 2 minutes, the table cloth is already changed, and I asked if they see my wallet, they said no. (I don't think the other guest took it because they were old couple having their vacation and they were sitting faraway from our table.)  I know I should make sure take care of my wallet to myself, but I am sure that I left my wallet there. I wanted to check the camera, one of the waitress talked to me she had to ask with her boss. She told me to come back next day. I was thinking if nobody (employees) took my wallet then I will just let it go. But I am 90% sure that one of them took my wallet. next day, and the day after next day, she refused me to take look at the record of that day. The reason is just because her boss is busy. This restaurant is the worst experience that I never had in my life.

This place gets crowded on weekends, but we were lucky enough to walk in about 10 minutes before the dim sum rush.

We were seated quickly and although it took a little longer than we would have liked to get drinks and dim sum service started, once the carts started coming around the food was plentiful and good.

We ordered a number of items and although not the best dim sum I've ever had, it was good and everyone in my party left satisfied. 

The decor and restaurant setup is lovely and there is plenty of space to accommodate many large parties, which is the best way to enjoy dim sum. The more is definitely the merrier here.

i usually go to eat dim sum on Decatur of las vegas, and the reason i came to this restaurant was a lot of people tell me they serve the best dim sum in las vegas.

first, i don't make any common on the taste of food, because since i start to eat dim sum, i think every dim sum restaurant taste same. i  didn't eat any dim sum that is bad on taste, i also didn't eat any dim sum that is perfect.

i wont say don't go this restaurant to someone, but i will not suggest this restaurant. 

their service is too f**king slow. i am OK if a popular restaurant get a little bit slow. but if a restaurant can make me mad because they sooooo slow, then they do have big problem on their management.  if you have eaten dim sum, you know they are served on little tapas style plates. One dish has little food on it. i started to eat at this kj restaurant at 10:30, and i f**king only ate got 4 plate in 2 and half hours!!!!!!!! finally, i asked the server if they can order my food for me, they say, go check the food cart, but where is the f**king food cart.!!! i finally take the to go, because i cant sit at there any more.

Horrible horrible service !!! 
Skip this place. I have never been in a place where I was not checked on .. we like the other kj better. Horrible ! 

Might as well serve ourselves

Dim sum here is amazing! I come here every morning that I'm in vegas pretty much for dim sum. The chicken feet and shu mai are very flavorful. The service is pretty good for it being so busy. Highly recommended

Not bad for Vegas standard! Siumai so so, cha siu bao so so, steamed taro good, steamed beef and cilantro roll good, chicken feet not sweet, beef ball no good, xlb not good, shrimp ball so so, ribs vey good! Price is very affortable. Bay area dim sum is still superior!!
whoever does not like this place is crazy. The best dim sum in town.
I like their Dim Sum, but only serve till 3pm or 4pm. Treat here as a Chinese brunch place, you won't disappointed.

Very busy place in Rio Casino & Resort. Nice & clean dinning area, good Chinese restaurant ambient. Dim sum selections are good. Service is pretty good & fast, dinner menu has good selections as well. Recommend to try.

This is the only place I would eat dim sum in Vegas because how fresh and yummy the food is, cleanliness, parking and service. I have been coming here shortly after they opened, so it has been a couple years now. Time to write them a review. 

Food- everything I have tried was fresh and yummy. I personally love leek and taro, so I really enjoy their leek items here. I have the following list that I order every time I go.

1.Teochew Dumplings (潮州粉粿)-- I enjoy their Teochew dumplings every time I go. This is a dumplings with clear noodle wrap and filled with leek, water chestnut and pork.  
2.Pan fried Leek Dumplings(韭菜餅)--love their pan fried leek dumplings as well. It's perfectly made with enough leek and meat to make it juicy not dry.
3. Shrimp in rice noodle wrap (蝦腸粉)-- this dish tastes the same at most dim sum places you go but their shrimp is a decent size. This item is on a must list whenever I go to dim sum as well.
4. Fried Taro pastries -- the crunchiness of the outside and the moist/ soft taro inside, yummy!!!! This dish is not a dessert, the taro inside is seasoned with salt and other stuff. 
5.Shumei -- their shumei is decent. I would say it's better than most places in Vegas but somehow I still love shumei from Jasmine inside of Bellagio the best. 
6.Shrimp dumplings/ Haogow-- it's also a must ordered dish when I go to dim sum. It's not too bad here also. 
7. Sticky rice wrapped in leaf -- I love sticky rice and this dish here is decent as well. Definitely give it a try.
8.Pineapple Buns -- I order this item from time to time. They have green tea flavor now which is different and interesting.
9. Tofu Dessert soup -- I love tofu and they are very generous with the portion. Silky tofu in ginger and sugar soup. Yummy.
10. Last not least. The famous Egg Tarts -- I love love love their egg tarts here. Majority of time when I ordered, it's hot and fresh like they just came out of oven. I have not tried egg tarts from golden gate bakery but this is one of the best that I tried before. Although I do wish they have Portuguese egg tarts here! 

Services-- they are usually busy so they are not as attentive as I would like them to be but they are usually very friendly even though you don't speak Cantonese. Unlike some other places in town, if you don't speak Cantonese In a Cantonese restaurants, you get some kind of attitude :/. 

Environment -- the place is big and clean. Also its got many TVs in here. 

All in all, I love this place. When I visited Koi Palace in SF (the famous dim sum place), I was not happy with an hour wait, the attitude was bad and the food was just okay. KJ dim sum you rock!

Even 1 star is more here. We used to be regular customer. My husband plays wsop and we stay at rio for the whole mints. Almost everyday we eat here.  Today we ordered chicken sweet corn soup and found a piece of plastic in the soup ! We couldn't eat anymore. All they did said sorry and gave $2 discount! Didn't bother to change the soup ! We came back not eating at last. I am never coming back again.
Fantastic value and even better food.  The house soup is to die for and desserts (during dimsum) are phenomenal.  Go there.  Now.

Loved it!
The complimentary soup and dessert were really nice. 
A little salty on dishes with soy sauce. 
But we had a great time there

my first Dim-Sum experience.  I went with my friend who speaks chinese and he ordered all kinds of stuff.  I really like the chicken feet.  Kinda weird to eat but very good.  the food is just great.  it helps if you know how to order first.  the steam table cart come right to your table and for the novice (me) it was a little overwhelming.  Im glad my friend was with me.  the place is packed at lunch and you will have to wait a little but its worth it.  very nice.
One of the best dim sum restaurants I have experienced.  Dim sum was fresh and great tasting.  I would definitely return here the next time I go to Las Vegas!

YELP 365 CHALLENGE 2014-(177/365) "Those Taro Buns Tho'!"

Still a great place to get your dim sum fix, and I'd like to hope much safer considering it is inside a Hotel/Casino as opposed to a free standing restaurant in Chinatown(I'm looking at you, Cathay House!) If you haven't seen that "Dirty Dining" segment, better check it out!

Everyone has their opinion on dim sum , and KJ is still in my top 3. They are fast, there are a lot of items to choose from, and from my experience here, they always got different things on the cart I haven't seen or tried. After grubbin' on some savory offerings, the dessert cart comes around and I grab my usual Rice Cakes and there are these buns with a white crunchy topping, so wifey asks about it and we find out they are Taro Buns. We get them, and it was love at first bite! They weren't real taro root though, it was purple sweet potato, and they were BOMB!

After paying our bill and on our way out, I spied similar looking buns on a cart and asked the lady what they were...They also have Green Tea Buns too which is another excuse to return!  ALOHA!!!


Shaka Meter:  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  4

Definitely in my top 2 of favorite dim sum list. This is located near the Carnival World Buffet inside Rio so take that into consideration when parking. We ended up parking on the opposite end. It's busy here but we only waited 10 minutes to get a table (on a  weekend). This has got to be nicest, fanciest and cleanest dim sum restaurant I've been to.

There were carts that would pass by every 5 minutes. I didn't see my favorite dim sum items though like the roast pork and deep-fried minced pork/beef dumplings. We were there for at least an hour so, I doubt we missed it.

We got har gow, siumai, chicken feet (I don't eat feet of any animal), roast duck, shrimp wontons, baked cha siu bao, steamed cha siu bao (BBQ pork buns), crispy shrimp roll, salt and pepper shrimps, egg custard, shrimp balls, calamari and sweet tofu. My favorites were: roast duck, shrimp balls and sweet tofu - they have the best version of these dishes in town. I've had sweet tofu that has a strong ginger flavor...KJ's version is just right.

Gimme sum dim sum!

NO STARS ACTUALLY!!!   
DO NOT COME HERE FOR DIM SUM!!!!  I REPEAT...DO NOT!  

My family and I frequent this place regularly for dim sum.  But yesterday was the last and dual final time I will be coming here.  

1st - they now charge $1 per person for tea, which normally I wouldn't mind, I understand tea gets expensive and can add up.  But the jasmine tea tasted like hot water with a hint of color to it, no Jasmine taste what so ever. 

Service is slow and servers all looked unhappy. I'm Chinese, and trust me I'm used to Asian restaurants with bad or no service, it just comes with dining at an Asian restaurant. Especially Chinese.  But this has got to be the worst I've had in a long time. 

Sat down, was asked what kind of tea would you like. Not aware $1 per person. I ordered the stream rice rolls with cilantro n green onion with the server.  15 minutes went by, not a single food cart. Entire restaurant 4 carts, steam cart, congee cart, miscellaneous food,  and Chinese broccoli cart.  The ladies were pushing them like the wheels were broken or something!  Finally the stream cart came by. We ordered 8 dishes my Mom, boyfriend, n myself) figured we load up since it took so long.  The same cart with the same food came by 3 times after that, no new items.  I asked for steamed tripe, and shrimp rice rolls and she looked around at the other carts and said "I don't have it."  

I finally get my order of cilantro and green onion rice roll, only to see a plan ol' plate of steam rolls, no herb. I told the lady I wanted cilantro n green onion. She walked up to the waitress that I placed my order with and told her next time not to write the word white in the order, white means plan. The waitress then comes over to the table and says, "the lady just started working a few days ago so she made the mistake. We have to make your another one."  In the meantime, no other carts came by but the 4 carts that had nothing that sparked my interest. Asked for egg custard tarts, nothing. Not a single one to be found. As time pasted, I got more and more frustrated as I watched the lady bring out cilantro green onion rice rolls to all the other tables that were seated AFTER us!  The table next to us had 5 orders of egg tarts delivered to their table.  So I decided to place one order and ask for the check...we were fed up at this point. 

The waitress took the check to tally up and added the order of egg custard to the bill.  She came back and said 15 minutes wait for the egg tarts.  So damn frustrated I said NO!  I can't wait anymore, I have to leave now (by now it's 90 minutes).  She walked away, went up to the cashier, came back n said ok 6 minutes ok because she already added the tarts on your bill.  I finally said fine and agreed.  15 minutes later...no tart in sight and the waitress kept dodging our table because she knew I was trying to get her attention.  Finally got her attention and she went to get them. I felt played for a fool.  

$50 later and we were all still some what hungry. Because of this almost 2 hour lunch, I was almost late to work.  

NEVER EVER EVER AGAIN!!!!!!!

My new favorite Chinese restaurant in town. Owned by the same folks of KJ kitchen on Spring Mountain. This location at The Rio is even better. I didn't think it was possible! The food is incredible, amazing service.Warning, it is pricier because it is more upscale and in a "casino", but worth it!  It's brand new, thus very clean, the decor is gorgeous, the ambiance has a romantic, gourmet feel. 20% I you're a local. I'm in heaven here

1. They charged us $1 per cup of tea for each person in our group even though only 1 person actually drank the tea (the remaining 5 cups were upside down on turntable).  The rest ordered sodas or water, so in addition to a $6 tea bill, we also had a $6 soda bill.
2. Their menu was not available because they were changing things, so when we ordered chicken fried rice off the menu, we had no idea how much it cost, and we were shocked to see our bill for $13.95 for a small plate of it.  
3. There were no prices on the dim sum either. Not even dishes marked A, B, C, D and no price points on any paper indicating what dishes A, B, C, D might cost so we were ordering blind.  When we asked, the dim sum cart ladies did not speak any English.
4. The dim sum cart ladies were scamming us by stamping our paper for more than they placed on our table.  I had to watch that stamping process very carefully and question everything (with hand gestures) and for some reason, we ended up being charged for 5 A dishes, 9 B dishes, and 4 C dishes, which is odd because the same items I order at other dim sum restaurants seem to be A dishes with an occasional B or C dish - again I felt scammed.
5. The bill for 4 adults, two children for lunch was $89 plus tip.  Typically when we eat dim sum at other restaurants with our Chinese friends, we have 5 adults and two children and our bill averages only $50-60, which is why we love dim sum so much.  There is usually so much value for the price.
6. Some of the food was good, but some of the hot food was cold.  Not impressed with anything.

We will never eat at KJ Dim Sum again.  There are just too many other great and trustworthy dim sum restaurants to eat at and those restaurants offer English menus with prices in plain sight so customers know how much they are paying and are not shocked by the bill.

I was pleasantly surprised when I came here for dim sum over the weekend! I never knew this awesome dim sum place existed at the Rio so close to the strip. I had previously always went to Chinatown to get dim sum whenever I was in Vegas. 

There were many dim sum carts, and a large variety of plates to chose from. Everything I tried was pretty good. My favorites were the fried taro, steamed bean curd, and shu mai. 

I really like how large and modern this place is. I also like that it feels clean, unlike some other Chinese restaurants.

RUDEST PEOPLE EVER- RIO, get another Chinese restaurant !

I had a COMP due to my endless Slot Play, lol, and was told to go to any restaurant other than Burger King. I had only 25 dollar credits but according to the Card Services is good for dinning in any restaurant.

I walk into KJ dim sum and the lady tells me " ohhhh, i don't know" and then says "fine fine do you want take out?"  I say no i want to stay in and eat.
She then proceeds to tell me that she can't look up the amount and the answer is NO.
I went to another restaurant and they had no problem giving me the 25 credit towards food.
NEVER AGAIN- KJ SUCKS AND YES, I AGREE WITH THE OTHER REVIEWER that they need to LEARN ENGLISH
I ordered lobster rolls and the majority was celery and carrots. Don't bother, go somewhere else.

We usually go here for dim sum and the food and service is good.  The dim is a little pricey but that's expected being that it's inside a casino.

So tonight we decided to stop by for dinner.  We weren't too hungry so we just ordered crab meat with fish maw soup and their "Imperial Peking Duck".

Soup: it was ok. Nothing special compared to other soups at restaurants in LA. $20 a bowl.

Duck: This was a total rip-off and I'll tell you why. The dish alone is $42 bucks !  That's about $10-$15 dollars over other restaurants in the area.  But we accepted the price since we knew Peking duck comes 2 ways and that would sort of make up for the price.  The usual crispy skin with bao buns and then minced duck with lettuce wraps is usually how the dish is served.

So they bring out the duck and it is the "complete" duck, meat and skin and all.  So we asked about the minced meat part with lettuce wraps.  They informed us that it would be extra charge.  $15 dollars extra to be exact.

The waiter kept telling us that they don't do it like LA restaurants. I don't know what he's talking about since restaurants in the area do duck 2 ways when you order Peking duck. I don't care where your at. When you order Peking duck, it is always served 2 ways and not charged EXTRA. The price on the menu is the price you pay!

Anyway.  We settled with what we had and asked about ordering more bao for our duck. We only wanted a couple more. The waiter first told us that you have to order by 3 or 6.  Then he comes back after checking with manager that minimum order is 6. The baos' are $.75 per !  

At this point we were totally dumbfounded and furiously frustrated by how badly we just got ripped off and how this restaurant tries to nickel and dime you with their outrageous extra charges.  

The waiter, sensing our great disappointment, offers us free dessert. It was taro with tapioca and was good, but not enough to dissuade me from writing this poor but deserving review.

The food was good and they did try to give us some sort of comfort with the free dessert.  For that, I give them 2 stars.

Definitely hits the spot but not the most amazing dim sum that I've ever had.

The restaurant is HUGE. Tons of tables so there was no wait. 
They also actually have carts which is nice, definitely a rare sight these days.

Xiao long bao: Medium skin, a little bit of soup and you get three in little individual tins. The tins are fun because they keep the soup in 

Ha/Sha chang fun: Woaaahh tons of the rice noodle wrapping and little shrimp but otherwise pretty good

Shumai: *two thumbs up*

Dan tat: We got it fresh...but definitely less egg yolk than other places. I like my dan tat really yellow otherwise they taste more like cream than anything

They also have kai lan, shi fan etc etc. Fairly authentic but I do feel as if there are some short cuts made ingredients wise. Definitely wouldnt complain to come back again but wouldn't put it on my must-visit list either

Staff is nice and no complains there either :)

This place was very good.  We came for lunch for the dim sum. There were three of us, so we ended up with a $60 bill, which averaged $20 a person. Not bad for tons of food. 

When it comes to Dim Sum, I like the fried taro the most, and theirs did not disappoint. Other items worth mentioning were the duck, fried rice, shrimp wontons, pork BBQ bun, and the taro donut and egg custard desserts. I don't know all the authentic names, so forgive my ignorance. I just know they were good!

Very good! I come from Los Angeles' lovely area of dim sum and this place was surprisingly delicious. The price range is $3-6 per dish, with $3-4 per plate for the classics shu Mai and har gow.

This is reasonably priced considering its a restaurant inside the rio hotel.

PS. They do charge $1 per person for drinking tea. :)
Horrible service. We have to w8 like forever before we can order anything to eat. And the veggie we ordered never comes up. It's better to go to Chinatown. It's way better there

My husband and I went here on Sunday morning for dim sum and was extremely disappointed. Here's why: (1) Their system for seating customers. When we got there at 11 am, it wasn't too busy. There were three parties ahead of us to be seated. They gave us a number. One of the members in the party after us must speak the language because he was right next to the hostess and kept asking her about when they would be seated. The next thing I know, our number was skipped and they got seated. We thought maybe it's because they have a bigger group and it was a bigger that table came available. Then she started seating other people that came after us. My husband told her that she skipped our number and then she seated us. (2) Little variety. We were seated in the middle of the restaurant with a large aisle. The whole time we were there, the same two carts came through. I asked one of the ladies if they had chicken feet. Instead of saying that she can have the person come over, she said "later". Later never came. (3) Service is poor. It was hard to flag down a waiter for refills or for questions. Once they seat you, the waiter does not come back to check on you. When we were done with being disappointed in the food and service and ready to leave, we could not get the attention of a waiter to check us out. My husband gave up and took our check to the register himself to pay it. This is one of the rare time that we did not leave a tip.

On the way out, the line was out the door. In my mind, after what I just experienced, it is NOT worth the wait.

My wife and I were a bit apprehensive before going to KJs because of some of the lower-star reviews posted.  Many of those reviews seemed to be based more on the staff than on the food, quality, or quantity.   My wife and I were greeted and seated within 30 seconds of arriving.  Tea was offered and brought to our table in under one minute.  We did have to request water, but refills were automatic and timely.  Multiple carts were always in motion and accessible.  The english of the wait staff was a bit difficult to understand, but it added to the ambience (and was much better than my Mandarin or Cantonese). Staff smiled, made recommendations and remained friendly throughout the meal.  Prices were based on food portions, small medium or large, ranged from $2-5.  Overall, very reasonable.  Favorites were any of the dumplings, shrimp, pork or chicken and the pork stuffed sticky buns followed by the sweet tofu dessert.  We left, completely stuffed like good Americans, for a total bill of $42.  Highly recommended.

For a little over $40, Earl and I enjoyed a delicious dim sum lunch, and some food leftover for breakfast the next day.

The servers were attentive, and the cart ladies were not pushy and remembered our turnip cake order.  We got there at 11:50ish on a Sunday, and we only waited for 10 mins before we got our table.  Within 10 minutes later, there was an ocean of people that came in and had to wait. 

We ordered all of our usual items and they were very good.  KJ will be our go to when we want some delicious dim sum.

Stopped by here to get some early dim-sum. This place opened earlier than any other dim sum place in Vegas at 10:00am. All other places opened at 11am.

The quality of the dim sum was okay. For some reason, their har gow was small in comparison to what Im used to. The flavors were not bad. Prices were reasonable considering it was inside a casino, albeit the kinda run down Rio Casino.

I think I'll wait until 11am next time I'm hankerin for dim sum in Vegas....

Wanted to check this place out for dinner because I heard their food was really good. Our party of 7 walked out of the place after waiting 30mins for service. No one came over to check on us! No tea!!! No water!!! No drinks!!! It was about 5pm and the place wasn't busy at all. There were 5 other tables with people in them besides ours. The staff paid more attention to cleaning and setting up tables than waiting on the guests. My husband kept trying to wave at them to get their attention. I'm pretty sure 2 servers saw him, and we still didn't get service! Then an older couple came to the restaurant and got seated and 2mins later a server was getting their order. We still don't know why they didn't come to our table. -.-

Closed even though they said open 24 hours.  Only visit here food was good but please have hours of operation that you actually adhere to.  This is ridiculous standing outside at 12:30 am it says online open until 2 am yet doors barred.  Get with the program or make way for another business that can.

Dim sum in Vegas?! Yes, please! 

The service here was really good. Some of the ladies pushing the cart actually spoke the some dialect as me, so that's a big plus for a Chinese place. The food is also pretty good. The egg tarts are a must here; they are delicious. I could eat a whole entree on my own. 

Pro tip: come early for dim sum on the weekend. If you wait until 12 ish, there will be a line.

Horrendous experience. Waiters don't speak English and push disgusting dishes on you as though they were free and then charge you a fortune for them. All the food was nasty, can't warn people enough to stay clear of this place.

Oh and still waiting after 10 mins to get bill. Place is half empty I've only been friendly to waiter and he acts like there's nothing to do in life. Takes a lot to get me this pissed at a restaurant!!!

Dimsum was VERY ordinary, nothing's taste special/ good. 168 market has a better tastier dimsum. 
Few of the ladies works there doesn't even speak English, I'm surprised casino would hire people who don't understand English even for a VERY simple conversations.
Long story short, we're not happy with the food and Will never comeback again.

Just recently took a trip to Vegas last weekend and stayed at the Rio hotel. My friend and I decided to give this dim sum place a shot since it's located inside the same casino. All of the items we ordered were either average or sub par. Yeah taste wise, nothing really stood out and I was pretty disappointed. Mehhh I wouldn't come back here again.

I was so impressed by how authentic their Chinese food tastes like.

When comes to food, I am more focus into taste than the decoration or quality of service.  You can give me so so service and serve me good food I will still give you 5 stars.

Located inside Rio Casino. This location is more expensive than its Chinatown original location.  However, the menus offers more choices.

Went there three days in a row during the recent Vegas trip.

Must get - Roast Duck, Fried Rice, House special daily soup, Beef with Vegetables.

Must try - shrimp dumpling, shumai, chicken feet (for lunch/dimsum).

Usually the waits are not too bad except lunch times for dim sum.  It is cheaper or on par with the dim sum restaurants in LA.  Very competitive prices!
Ok dim sum. Not so many choices. Someone recommended this place is one of the best dim sum but I have had better back in Hawaii. Disappointed. Prob never come back.
Good dim sum if a bit inconsistent.  Looooong wait on the weekends.  Beats the shitty atmosphere of the dim sum joint next door at the Gold Coast I think it's called.

A little bit of China inside Vegas, at the Rio. Peking Duck, don't ever forget the bun and hoisin sauce. Watch out for the market price on seafood. Our party of nine split a crab for $202.50 although it was a mighty full size crab and quite beautiful in presentation. High rollers and authentic Chinese tourists will dig the regular and special menu. It still doesn't beat the wonders of Monterrey Park, however. #crabbywhiteguy

I gamble alot, possibly more than any other human being that's known to exist in this third dimensional world.  As we all know, gambling drains the hell out of everyone and definite stimulates our appetite.  I am a frequent stayer at the Rio and fortunately for myself, dining at KJ has to be one of the most nostalgic experiences I've had.

Let's get one thing straight:  This is not an average Chinese restaurant.  The place is pretty decent in terms of size and has the patience to deal with people that don't really have that patience.  I seriously admire the service staff for putting up with people don't have patience.  They are quick, friendly, and extremely hospitable and that goes without saying that this is the most important aspect of a restaurant.

Food is awesome.  How awesome you say?  Well besides the traditional types of dimsum, you also have to count this restaurant for dinner.  I've had some pretty interesting experiences as well as some nostalgic ones.  You have classic stir fried dishes like Kung pao, as well as individual dishes like crispy chow mein with gravy.  Though that is more of the American side of Chinese cooking, there are some delight-able treats that they have here for an authentic Chinese palate.  I hate to say if anything is truly better than anything else, but they have the best steamed chinese fish that I've ever had and let me remind you that I am a VERY picky eater.  Be warned though, the price is expensive (40 USD for a pound).

Although I won't eat Chinese food everyday but I can appreciate it as it has always been something I've grown into.  If you're around, you just have to stop by and try it for yourself.  I'll be back when I return to my gambling habits once again!

Better than Chang's...except for the price.

We were really craving dim sum and the dim sum at Caesar's palace buffet just didn't cut it. If you're used to really good dim sum from Norcal, this place just won't do...however if you're used to dim sum anywhere else, this might be okay.

Like every dim sum place, there's hits and misses. Their baked bbq pork buns? Good. Chicken feet? Not bad, but i've had better. Sticky rice in lotus leaf? flavorless. Shrimp dumplings (har gow)? Tasty but incredibly small. Chinese Broccoli with oyster sauce? Surprisingly good! Tofu pudding? Texturally disappointing...not smooth at all! 

for 5 people we spent about $100. Yeah, we ordered beef chow fun and chicken wings but wow...$100 for dim sum?!?! I guess I should have expected as much seeing that this is a casino.

The service as others have mentioned is pretty crappy but if you're used to authentic Chinese restaurants you know that long as you're teapot is filled, that's all you can really ask for.

I'm writing this review based on my experience over this past Sunday. The restaurant is located inside of a off-strip hotel (RIO) so it's reasonable to expect that a lot of patrons who dine here are guests of the hotel and a mix of locals. I am the latter and neither myself or my dining guest were of Chinese nationality.

We were sat in the middle of the restaurant during a moderately busy Sunday early afternoon and were quickly approached by the food carts (we had no qualms with the delivery of food, with the exception that some dishes were served cold when they should have been hot). 

A waiter then approached us once and asked for a drink order. Other than that, there were no efforts made to check on the table. We tried several times to flag down a waiter to get some basics (chili sauce, soy sauce, napkins, etc.) and were met with quick turns of the head as if they "didn't see us." After several minutes of being what we felt were purposely ignored, we noticed these same waiters were very attentive and visited several times the tables seated with all Chinese or mostly Chinese guests. Finally I was able to get the attention of a gentleman I assumed to be the restaurant manager who asked if we needed something. After requesting my simple condiments I received an eye roll from the gentleman and then an "ok." After observing him going back and fourth to other tables after waiting 10 minutes for the delivery of two simple items, we noticed he went back to the main reception desk and stood there, not making an attempt to deliver the items to us. We then had to literally almost grab a hold of another waiter before they acknowledge our presence and again requested our simple condiments, that were then promptly delivered. The (assumed) manager then walked to a table of women sitting next to ours and proceeded to have a full on conversation, even going so far as to sit down at their table and socialize. I did notice on two occasions that he did glance our way and give a rude, irritated look our way as they proceeded to talk. At this point both my partner and myself were fed up with the incredibly rude, purposeful lack of service at our table and asked for the check, which they were quick to get us and wisk away as soon as we put out cash in. When the server looked in the pocket and noticed that I had given 3 $20 bills on a $58.35 check, she asked if we were ready to pay and I nodded yes, she then stood there for a few seconds with a look that almost said, are you kidding with this? no tip? which was purposeful on our account. 

This may sound like a rant, and it is, but I want to make it perfectly clear that we were treated with indifference and rudely the entire experience, for what seemed no other reason than that we were not Chinese. 

For a restaurant located inside of a hotel to provide this sort of service to it's guests and guests of the hotel is unheard of. This experience reflects poorly not only on the restaurant but the hotel itself. 

So my suggestion, if you are not Chinese, then don't dine here because they obviously and clearly do not want your business. Next time, I'll go to a establishment on Spring Mountain.

Been to so many different places over the years and I'm sure later on this place will be like the rest. As of now it has the best tasting dim sum in town. This is the only place I go. It cost a little more but worth it.

I had high expectations for this place bc it was highly recommended &  took a trip to eat here. Dont ha e high expectations! I thought the food was good,  nothing amazing like i cant get anywhere else. But i was pretty disappointed in the amount of dishes they provided.  I get it,  its a tuesday. Maybe they have better food on the weekends,  u tell me. And they had maybe 5 carts of different things going around,  3 being tofu & congee & chinese broccoli. We got 6 dishes off of the first cart. Thinking theres gonna be more,  there wasnt. What we got was pretty much their staple. And the restaurants was 1/2-3/4 full,  but only have one cart of each going around is a bit slow to me.. But whatever idc. Just disappointed in the fact that there wasnt as much options. I can get alot more dishes at other dimsum spot ive tried in the midwest. And i had to ask for certain dishes because it wasn't on the cart (even tho i saw them bring it to other requesters). 
My favorite thing there is probably the egg tarts. So much flavor abd u can taste the custard in it,  alot of places dont hit that right spot for it.  Their dessert is probably what i would come back for if im really craving it. 
Service is bad,  which i knew coming in, no expectations there. Food is good but not that many options,  maybe go on the weekends for more options. But was disappointed.

This place has legit Chinese food! Whenever I'm in Vegas and crave Chinese, I come here. The quality of the food is 5 stars. Here's what I recommend: walnut shrimp, roast duck, peppered steak, beef chow fun, and black bean clams. I usually stay at the Palms, so it's really convenient for me. Two thumbs up!

Quite yummy dim sum dishes! Nothing too spectacular. Was in Vegas for a few days and this was our first stop after arriving. We were recommended this dim sum location by someone who lived in Vegas locally. I actually don't know what the total was on the bill, so I can't compare the prices of the dishes here to other dim sum locations. Food wasn't "WOW", but customer service was defitnetly GREAT! 

We came on a Friday morning a bit after 10:00am so we were able to grab a table and was quickly seated. A little over an hour later, when we were leaving the restaurant, there was a waiting line to get a seat outside the retaurant! So I would defitnetly go early if you can unless you don't mind waiting for a table.

Decent priced food considering it's Vegas and it's open pretty late. The food is average, but you  can't really complain considering the price and the fact that it's Chinese food in the center of Vegas

Had a free room at the Rio, so we used it (not why 4 stars). 49ers broke my heart that night.

49ers lost. To themselves. They would've won the superbowl.

UGH.

So we went down to KJ. The line for Carnival was horrendous. 

We got seated immediately.

It was just my fiance, our three year old, and I. So we got some chow fun, some dim sum, and..... duck feet. I actually just changed this to five stars thinking about the duck feet.

The chow fun was great, exactly how you'd expect it. The dim sum (I grew up in Hong Kong) was great, exactly how you'd expect it (if you know what to expect). The duck feet. Oh. My. God. The duck feet is why I'm going back, it's an appetizer so not tooo pricey but they perfected the flavor. 

I didn't win (I only play poker-against people, not casino) at the Rio on my free stay,the 49ers lost because of themselves, but I consider the trip a God Send because of KJ. 

And yes, we had breakfast, and dinner at Carnival, which was really good. I dream of the next time we goto KJ and try the Sea Cucumber.

If you haven't been to KJ, in my opinion. Try. This. Place. Don't settle for the Dim Sum. Try. This. Place. Order at least one dish from their MENU, not the dim sum menu. Their menu.... (So, my advice is TRY MORE than dim sum. Hell, they advertise themselves as a seafood restaurant!!)

The ambiance was great. It's so awesome to actually have Chinese servers in a Chinese restaurant that all speak English you speak respect, or humanity? Towards them first... I was slightly intoxicated and stumbled upon open kitchen doors, and are you kidding me? There were Chinese cooks!

There is a really great picture of recent Hong Kong Island on one of the walls, my son loved that as we have smaller versions in our house.

Food was 5 star service 4, in our three person experience. Maybe because I'm a white guy that speaks Cantonese? 

I'll be going back. Soon.
The service is much better than most Chinese Restaurants! The food is very authentic! We came here for dinner and was very satisfied.

Came here for dinner.... But food was okay, not the greatest. We order 4 items. The sweet and sour spareribs, weren't fresh. The meat that was use wasn't fresh and just didn't taste right. Also ordered the salt and pepper shrimp and that didn't look fresh either as they had use very cheap shrimp to cook the dish. The color of it didn't look appealing like other places. Overall the food was okay.

Maybe I'm a dim sum snob because I'm from the Bay Area and am fortunate to have eaten great dim sum. Other than in the Midwest, this may be some of the worst dim sum I've eaten. When frozen dumplings from Trader Joe's or the Asian supermarket taste better, you have a problem. Unless you really have a hankering for dim sum and can't get it anywhere else where you live, I would recommend eating something else.

This is located inside the Rio, across the from the buffet. We didn't have a problem getting a table for 7 when we arrived around 11 am but there was a wait when we left around noon.

The service for the carts was extremely slow - I don't know if that's normal, or if was a function of where we were sitting.

Best Dishes:

Har Gow - Shrimp Dumpling - This actually tasted normal, and 4 pieces per order. The size of each dumpling was smaller than you usually get elsewhere.

Crab & Shrimp Dumpling - This was one of my favorites from what we ordered.

Mediocre / Nothing to Write Home About: Sticky Rice in Lotus Leaf, Steamed BBQ Pork Buns, Chinese Broccoli, Shrimp in Rice Noodle (the rice noodle portion was a bit on the thick side and the shrimp was a little sparse)

Pass: Fried Calamari - this tasted like it had been deep fried yesterday and nuked in the microwave. Not fresh at all. Veggie Dumplings - These actually have shrimp in there, but the veggies and shrimp didn't taste very fresh.

The one saving grace was that it was inexpensive - our bill pre-tip was $65 for 7 people, but you also get what you pay for. The food was edible, but I wouldn't crave this or make a special trip to go here. There are far better places to eat in Vegas.
The restaurant is large, which is nice. It is located right across from the Rio's Carnival Buffet. The Dim Sum was quite good, the best I've had so far in Vegas. Not too expensive.

Went there with a couple of my buddies today for lunch. Everything that we sampled from the cart was delicious, and the three of us waddled away from the table, stuffed to the point of pain, for only $36. I will DEFINITELY return.

I said it before and I'll say it again... if you walk into a Chinese restaurant and all of the patrons and servers are Chinese, I would say it's a good sign.  And it was.  This dim sum place reminded me of a famous dim sum place in Hong Kong.  So many options and the servers were around often with the carts so there was no waiting at all.  They had a lot of authentic dim sum.... on the day we went, they had a special duck egg bao.  My friend's Chinese mom was quite pleased.  And those egg tarts... wow! 

And I've read some of the other reviews about the prices, but I thought the prices were very reasonable.  In fact, there were 6 of us dining and the bill was only $75!!!  Amazing!  And we even ordered a noodle dish off the menu!  

And FYI, they don't have their liquor license yet, so BYOB!  We had a little cooler of our own beer and it worked out just great!

You ever have the problem of finding nothing but oil filled dim sum? I did until I was introduced to this magical place.

I grew up on dim sum as a kid, so you could say I'm a connoisseur of the sort. Not only does this place have the classic dishes (i.e. shumai, spare ribs, etc.) but they offer a variety of dumplings I've never come across.

Items to try:
1] steamed scallop & mushroom dumplings
2] panfried pork, mushroom & spinach mini pancake looking things
3] steamed veggie dumplings

Have at it at this place! I know I always do.

We ordered duck and orange chicken.  They were high quality for about $12 each.  the service was great but we were one of the handful of tables, so slow night.  

this was one of the only places that was still open to eat late at night.

I was thinking of giving KJ 3.5 stars, but I rounded it to 4 because of the great company with whom I had brunch here on Saturday.

The carts came around often with good selections.  I am happy I got to go again for dim sum with a Chinese speaking friend.  There's no language barrier and they often know what to order or what to avoid.  Such was the case Saturday with Li Ly, our friend who is moving back to San Francisco and the reason 7 of us got together for brunch.

We had shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, sesame balls, sweet buns, and some good shrimp balls.  I don't know the Chinese names for any of these, but they were generally good.  

We had fairly good service although Li Ly had to dig her heels in and get the service we needed.

I like the room.  It's well appointed and the decor is bright and roomy.

One of my favorite spots in vegas.  It is inside the RIO, so plenty of parking.  

The carts are continuously moving thru the dinning room.  Wonderful selection, wonderful textures and flavors.  My only issue is that most of the women with the carts speak only halting english.  As an adventurous dinner, this is heaven since I often won't have a clue what is being placed on my plate.  what will be inside my dumpling?  Pork?  Shrimp?  Something else?  doesn't matter, They all taste GREAT!

My guidelines to enjoying good dim is to only go on the weekends and during prime time. There is almost always a wait, but at least the food is hot and fresh. 

This is my go-to spot when I get a craving. Food is pretty consistent and the service is better than what I've received at other dim sum places. Their tripe is really good, and custard filled pineapple buns are a must!

WONDERFUL DIM SUM DURING A WEEKDAY

Service is pleasantly and surprisingly prompt.  Shrimp cheong fun, hom suy gock; steamed watercress roll, preserved egg rice porridge, steamed rice flour cake; green tea buns, shrimp with leeks rig, sweet tofu all piping hot delivered in roving carts.

Good or bad... Majority of diners are overseas Asians. We coincidently parked at the Masquerade Village garage as an excuse to walk off the fulfilling and most satisfying  dim sum lunch. 

Momo's newly found favorite is the amazing green tea bun !!
This is my favorite dim sum place in town. Every time I have gone, the service & the food have been great. It's reasonably priced and a wide variety of generous portions. Highly recommend.

Located inside a bright and cheerful dining room in the Rio, and offering much better quality than other dim sum spots in Vegas, I'm a fan of KJ! They will make items for you if you ask, and serve dim sum all day and late into the night. Five of us threw down a pretty eclectic variety of breakfast, my favorite items:

Congee: comforting with Century egg. 
Salt and Pepper Squid: perfectly executed.
Walnut Shrimp: deliciously decadent! 
Shrimp Balls: bite sized balls of goodness :) 
Egg Custard: my favorite in Las Vegas. 
Red Bean Bun: savory, fluffy bun.
Shiu Mau: appreciate the roe. 
Chive Balls: not at all greasy. 
Sweet Tofu: flavorful without being cloying. 
Taro Bun: so very good, real taro flavor. 
Chinese Broccoli with Garlic: superfresh™
Sesame Balls: sweet, nutty, tasty balls! 
XLB: everyone loved them: I don't eat pork, but they were soupy for sure! 

Service is pretty good, they are very busy during weekend prime-time. New items are added to the menu occasionally, and there's more hits than misses, IMO. 3.5* rounded up.

* bright, cheerful & bustling room inside Rio*

** wide array of dim sum options, served all
day (open late- till 2AM DAILY) ** 

*** will make items for you if asked *** 

**** new offerings added to keep it fresh ****

I was surprised that the Rio opened a dim sum place, but I was excited about trying it out.

I loved the interior. It's probably the nicest cleanest dim sum place you might find in Vegas. Not that others aren't nice, it's just been remodeled very nicely!

As for the dim sum, I'd have to say it's A-OK. Even the prices, I believe probably a tad higher than most, but I didn't mind if I'm sitting in a place I enjoy. The service, probably much the same as other Chinese dim sum restaurants, semi-friendly (?), efficient, but very rushed and a bit frantic.

I'd recommend KJ's for your next dim sum lunch :)

My favorite Vegas spot.  I have to eat here no matter where in Vegas I stay.  It is always on the list.  Fry cart is the best!  Steamed broccoli and green tea cakes are a must.  3 people a full table and hot tea for $50???  Can't beat that in Vegas!

I just got back from KJ Kitchen. I am still upset with the service. 
Especially the restaurant name is on total rewards gift card participating outlets LIST BUT they did not take it. One of girls said because the card has Discover card logo on it. It is the hotel gift card. I explained that but the manager and others just ignored me. Very rude. They forced me to pay in cash. Maybe they just wanted cash? 

I am contacting the Harrahs group they belong to now.

*Thumbs up*
They offer that egg custard bun which oozes out warm, neon-orange colored, yolk-flavored sweet custard. Not all dim sum places offer this delectable pastry, which is my favorite.

*Thumbs down*
Overall, quality has gone down significantly. The dim sum portions looked smaller and more shriveled up. They were served almost at room temp, and it didn't help that we were seated directly under an AC vent going full blast. Service still takes forever.
Great food.  Excellent service.  VERY recommended.  Right inside The Rio west entrance.

My new obsession for this place can be equated to these words: Baked Salty Egg Yolk Cream Bun. When I went to KJ for the second time in about a week with a friend, my husband made me get three orders of the mouth watering treat to go. He said don't bother coming home without it. True story.

KJ Dim Sum is located in Rio, across from the Carnival World Buffet. Tip: Prime parking is if you turn on Valley View, there is a parking lot and garage that is MUCH closer than if you enter through the main entrance.

The restaurant is large and can accommodate large groups. Just be prepared for a wait if you go during prime hours. The wait staff is good. They kept checking that our tea pot was full every few minutes.

They have a great selection of dim sum, a lot of the usual that I get in other dim sum places in town. Surprisingly, the prices are very good for being in a casino. I wish I knew the names of the items I love... I just point to whatever looks good! I love this fried seafood ball that comes with a mayo dipping sauce. Their shu mai is also very tasty. But like Tony T. said twice, and I will also mention two more times, the Baked Salty Egg Yolk Cream Bun will win you over!

KJ Dim Sum & Seafood serves mouthwateringly good dim sum at a very competitive prices (S $2.28, M $3.18, L $3.98, SP $4.98).  The restaurant is large with high ceiling, which is nice and gave it a cavernous airy feeling. It is located right across from the Rio's Carnival Buffet, so if you paid too much attention to the line of people waiting for the buffet, you might have to bust a U-ey like I did earlier today.

The dim sum selection is pretty vast.  They have all the usual popular dim sum items and some rare gems (highly recommend #32 Baked Salty Egg Yolk Cream Bun is a nice dessert to finish off your meal, but we also used it as our intermission break).

The food were hot every time we ordered it off the dim sum cart and the servers were friendly and timely in refilling tea pots, getting us extra hot sauces and napkins, and clearing away empty plates.

Overall, the food was good. Perhaps not as great as the top dim sum destinations up and down California. However, their Baked Salty Egg Yolk Cream Bun (it is so good I am mentioning it twice) with their golden liquidy center is reason enough for me to designate KJ Dim Sum & Seafood as my reigning Las Vegas dim sum spot.  

(Review was based on dim sum experience only, but they do have a regular Chinese restaurant menu offering as well).

Ambiance:  4/5  Airy, dining environment with pleasing decor.  

Food:  4/5  Overall good. 

Value:  4/5  Competitively priced.

Service:  4/5  No complaints.

Parking:  4/5  Parking garage, valet at the Rio.  Might have to stalk some pedestrians back to their car when it is busy.

Cleanliness:  4/5  Pretty clean.

Solid 4 stars in my book.

Great authentic Chinese food! It was worth the 30 minutes wait to get in there enjoy great dim sum with reasonable price. I would suggest that people to get to the place early most of the time since there is always a bit of waiting. The shumais and the chicken feet are really good.
The dim sum was amazing, but the service could have been better. We went on a day that wasn't very busy, but we were left sitting with the check until we finally walked it over to someone.

It is the best dim sum you probably can get in Vegas but wouldn't say the best dim sum I had eaten.  Also they are very busy, I literrally have to wait 10 minutes to get some dipping sauce and 15 minutes to get the check.

Service sucks!  I cant believe service can get this bad.  We got seated and was super hungry.  All the server tries to ignore helping us but 1, and her name is Queenie.  Many people there was hungry and many walked over to the dim sum cart but got yelled by dim sum cart lady to tell us to be patient and go back to our table.  Other server, especially Matthew (unbelievable, totally ignored us) refuse to bring us some orders and told us to wait until dim sum cart came.  We only got a chance to order few items.  End up most food was brought over by Queenie.  Reallie didnt want to tip anyone but for Queenie, we did.

Very fresh!  In addition to the traditional dim sum dishes, they also have the dumplings that usually come in the wooden steamers which are loaded with juice.  Good atmosphere being inside the Rio Hotel.  Definitely recommend checking it out.

Water was served room temperature and never refilled. Server was very very slow and didn't even get all of the orders in at my table. Getting the bill took forever and the only time the staff seemed to care was when I got my card out to pay.

Do not come here!!!! The worstttt service EVER!!! They charge you for freaking tea!? We had 6 people and it was $6 for tea. Wtf is that!? If I could give 0 stars, I definitely would! They do not care about their customers. We didn't get to eat much because no one came around to serve us. Avoid this horrible dim sum place. Their food isn't even good either. STAY AWAY!

Never thought I would find decent dim sum and cantonese food at a Las Vegas hotel/casino but, we did. Even my in-laws liked the food here and that says a lot. We are all from or eat regularly at Chinese restaurants in the San Gabriel Valley so we know what authentic Chinese food taste like. 

The place looks pretty nice and the service was pretty good. Wasn't hard to get the attention of the wait staff. The dim sum was pretty decent. The only problem we had with it was that it wasn't piping hot like we would find at NBC in Monterey Park. We also had dinner here as it was about 50 degrees outside with a bracing wind and didn't want to take the in-laws outside. We were pretty satisfied with the dinner too. The pork chop with spicy salt was good as I had at any Sam Woo and the sauteed pea shoots were very tender and delicious. 

The prices were of course higher than anything in the San Gabriel valley but, they weren't as bad as I thought they would be. However, it you want a bargain, just drive a couple blocks north to Spring Mountain Rd. and try one of the many asian restaurants there.

I've been here a few times before and it used to be better.  My shanghai dumpling was hard on top and mushy at the bottom and the shu mai had tons of cartilage in it. They get the 2 stars because of their delicious chrysanthemum tea and I love their chili sauce. Too bad the food isn't what I remember. My search for quality dim sum continues for Las Vegas. Sad!!!

Landed late and had dinner at this restaurant located inside of the Rio Hotel. The service and food were very good. It's a large restaurant and nicely decorated. The rice soup and baby bok choy was awesome.

The Dimsum was average just like any dimsum I had in the past and I stll think Ping Pang Pong is much better place for dimsum!  The price is ridiculously cheaper but for a quality, I will go back to P3!

Overall very good quality Chinese food. The service was very good (tell me another Chinese place that actually has people pouring your tea for you!!!). It took a while for our food to come out but it was worth the wait. We ate the corn soup (very delicious!) and we also got the seafood chow mein (so-so), the Kung pow chicken (the best dish of the night!), Mongolian beef (very good as well!), and the Chinese broccoli (lacking in oyster sauce but still good). The prices were what you would expect from a Chinese restaurant (overall we paid about $90 for five family style dishes). And the decor was nice! :) I would definitely come back~

As a bay area born and raised local Vegas resident, I would say the dim sum is not comparable to that of California, but it is one of the best in the city. 

Food: Sure it's not as good as Cali, but they don't take shortcuts here. The food that comes out of the kitchen taste and looks like what its suppose to be. The texture of the food tastes like what's it is suppose to. Most of the dim.sim is hot like It's suppose to when it is served to your table. I cannot vouch for the plate dishes as I've only had the dim sum. 

Atmosphere: It's clean, spacious, nice air conditioning, great service, and there's four LCDs for you to watch while you eat. They have TVB Mwhahaha

Come back? Yes, and I would recommend this place over places like Orchid, East Ocean, and even Ping pang pong. I would still recommend Chang's if you are on a budget, but you get what you paid for and your experience won't be as great.

5 star dim sum in my book!

There were some "BEST-Ive-had" dim sum items here!

For example, the Roast Duck. Easily the best I've had at dim sum! Skin was crispy, meat was tender and flavorful. Awesome!  You can find better if you look REALLY hard in Chinatown, but for dim sum, there has been no close second!

The Fried Shrimp Balls. These were easily the BEST I've had! I really don't know how they get ALL that flavor inside, but they are awesome!  Seriously, I have NEVER ordered items to take to-go...usually dim sum is oily and gross reheated....THIS was my first time, and surprisingly, they were actually good the second time around too LOL!

Salt and Pepper Squid. Another winner! This was soo good...so much flavor here, and much better than the shimp version!  If you like this kind of dish, do yourself a favor and order it :P

Shu Mai. This was very tasty and better than the others I've had before. Lots of flavor in the shrimp!  

Cha Siu Bao. These were tasty, but very small compared to all the others I've had before. Still one of my favorites! 

Egg Custard Buns...So good!  Again, very small portions, but they pack tons of flavor inside! This version was a little more "runny" inside than most. 

And remember to finish off with the Sweet Tofu! It is a tasty rendition here :)

Got a new favorite in town!

Pics :

I thought I researched this place adequately beforehand, but I totally messed up--dim sum is only served during the day!  At night, the restaurant only serves a very small (8 items) dim sum menu.  It almost broke my heart.

Even so, we still had a great dinner.  Very authentic Chinese menu.  We loved EVERYTHING we ordered off the dim sum menu, and since each item is served with 3 to 4 pieces, we made some repeat orders of our favorite things.  

Great food, attentive service, great prices!

Ordered 2 items and bowl of rice for dinner one night while in Vegas.  The sweet & sour pork came right out and was Ok.  Had to flag someone down each and everytime we needed something (dirty plate, soy sauce, etc) The water guy refilled my glass once.The waiter was very bored with taking out order, he couldnt look at us at all.  After finishing our small bowl of rice (extra cost) and pork we decided to cancel the rest of out order (kung pow shrimp).  Very low class place and poor service.  Wont make that mistake again! Vegas has so many wonderful places to eat - dont bother with this one.
Where's the food?. We are sitting here waiting and waiting for food.  We also have to return two basket of sticky rice chicken wrap because they were spoiled. We are still waiting ....,.

Arrived at Rio hotel past 12pm, almost all restaurants were closed so for convenience and the only opinion was here. Neutral feeling at first, but the staffs, I don't know if they were tired or just was having a bad day they were really slow with everything bringing in the food or just a glass of water and there was only us and this one other group. Once my uncle asked about a dish he didn't know the waiter just simply said it was good. 

The worst part was that I didn't get to eat some dim sum because they said they didn't serve them past midnight which is absurd since this restaurant has the word Dim Sum in their name. 
Well other than the service, the place was actually big, clean and the foods were actually good.

tldr

Extremely fast, lazy Susan's, plentiful menu

Get:
-Cantonese style beef (off menu)
-pan fried noodles
-beef chow fun
-crab maw soup
-Chinese broccoli

Normally I am not a fan of Chinese food. Like at all. However, we ate here with the family for a late dinner. By far, the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. Very very authentic Chinese food. We ordered the honey walnut shrimp, cashew chicken, and lo mein chicken. WOOOW. Wasn't heavy at all and was very filling.  The restaurant itself was very traditional old school type of Chinese restaurant which was pretty cool. Hosts and servers were all very polite and friendly. Price was very very affordable for really goood quality/authentic food. Overall I can't even think of one bad thing about this place. Great experience, excellent food.

We were in Vegas a couple of weeks ago for a Seminar and wanted to try some authentic chinese Food.
We tried out KJ Dim Sum at the Las Vegas Rio Resort and boy was that an awesome Brunch. 
Everything was so delicious and well prepared with a super nice staff.
Go try this place, you will love it.
When the Bill came I could not believe how inexpensive it was for that quality of Food.

We'll be back for more next time when we are in Vegas.

It's NEW! Dim Sum inside the RIO casino!  

After so many yelpers raving about the dim sum here I just had to try it for myself! Thanks to all the wonderful yelpers out there, I wasn't disappointed. 

Good quality and freshness made the dim sum items taste pretty good. There was always a good amount of food circulating on the carts. I really recommend ordering the rice rolls here! They are probably the BEST rice rolls I've had in a LONG time!! My only complaint is that there wasn't enough variety of dim sum items and the portions were kinda smaller than what I'm used to getting in LA. 

I didn't try dim sum anywhere else in Vegas, but I'm going to trust the other yelpers and agree that for the quality of the dim sum items here, the price wasn't too bad. The bill came out to be around $50 for 4 people, which is more than what we are used to paying in LA but it is Vegas so I guess it's expected that it's a bit more. 

Overall: I would totally recommend dim sum here!
Wow one of if not the worst buffet in Vegas! Over priced, none of the fruit was ripe, food tasted like wax , and worst of all the water taste like TOILET WATER. AWFUL

Decent dim sum restaurant located inside Rio.  We came here on Sunday for Mother's Day and surprisingly the wait wasn't too bad. We waited about 30 mins for a table for 5.  

There wasn't that many ladies pushing the carts but they seemed to stop by pretty often.  We ordered Chinese Broccoli and Crispy Noodles from our server and the rest from the ladies with the carts. 

Everything tasted decent.  My favorite was the Shu Mai- I could eat like ten of these. I don't know the names for the rest of them but they were all pretty decent, just a tad bit oily.  I also liked the custard egg tarts; it was freshly made as the custard was piping hot but so good.  

Again, decent dim sum place but nothing really stood out.  The ladies seemed to only have a couple of different dim sums as there wasn't much variety available when they came by to our table.  I was looking for a few specific ones but they were nowhere to be found :(.

AWESOME DIM SUM!!!! Good price and amazing selection. My only complaint is that it's a mystery at times what you are getting as some of the server's are not good with speaking english. Maybe some pics with explanations would help. I highly recommend eating here.

You'll find all your dim sum favorites here so never fear! I find that other places lack certain things like the fried taro, fried shrimp balls, sticky rice, and the steamed tofu wrap filled with chicken. Prepare yourself for an MSG-induced food coma because this meal will knock you out no matter how much tea you knock back.

Of course, given that they're located inside a casino, their prices are higher than a typical dim sum. Their spacious dining area is clean and decorated well, yet still has the atmosphere and buzz of a traditional Chinese restaurant. With all the waiters and pushcart ladies quickly making their rounds, their service runs as smooth as the wheels on the metal carts. Be sure to park on the west side of the Rio so the waddle back to the car is shorter!

Though it's a tad more expensive than usual, the scrumptious food and tip-top service solidify its claim on the best dim sum in Vegas in my book. Now if you'll excuse me, it's time for me and my happily full stomach to rest and digest.
Very good for the price. Fast service. I am amazed by the variety. It is in the Rio with a great staff. My buddies and I loved it. Great food and environment

Every time I go to vegas to visit my mom, it always ends with dinner at the other KJ location.

When I came to visit again and only had time for lunch, I was surprised when she asked me to meet her at the KJ located in the Rio for dim sum.

Surprisingly, the Dim Sum here was not bad. A bit pricey, but decent.
